12.21.21  11:32 am   How can I make my instruments sound clear and isolated from one another without EQing them to death?

      i only know 3 tricks for this. 1: pan them. 2: use less instruments in the first place. 3: low cut all the non-basses. #3 changed my life but i suspect there's more to the story

12.21.21  7:24 am   Hey Bill, got yet another music theory question for ya. I'm going through a song, looking at it's chords to get a better understanding of it and I want to go through and write the roman numerals and type (maj, min, dim, etc) so like I-ii-V-vi etc etc. Problem is, this is one of those songs that doesn't sit neatly in major or minor. It has one flat, starts on a D minor chord but resolves most of the time to F major, however, it resolves to a D minor at the very end. So, to the point, do I write the numerals in terms of the minor key (i-ii°-III-iv-v-VI-VII) or the major key (I-ii-iii-IV-V-vi-vii°)? Thanks so much

      i personally don't use roman numerals because they make my eyes hurt, but, in terms of deciding whether your minor root is called 1 or 6..... it's your choice. it's like choosing what you want for breakfast, which i understand is easier said than done

      99.9% of the learning on this is going to take place while the other players are there and you are actually playing together

12.19.21  2:12 am   Hey bill, what's the deal with secondary dominants? Can they be used for anything other than changing key?

      this may or may not help with your situation, but it will help with something. play these 3 notes at the same time:
     D (bass range, about 2 octaves below middle C)
     F# (just below middle C)
     C (middle C)
     
     then play these 3 notes at the same time:
     G (bass range, about an octave and a half below middle C)
     F (just below the F# from before)
     C (middle C)
     
     then play these 3 notes at the same time:
     C (bass range, 2 octaves below middle C)
     E (just below the F from before)
     C (middle C)
     
     then, write down (approximately) the 3 chords you just played, like this:
     D7    G7sus4    C
     
     if all goes well, the next time you hear a song with this thing in it, you will get a mild twinkle of knowingfulness in your mind, and you'll say, "ah yes, that's that thing"
